IndeterminateBeam Reference¶

Main module containing the main class Beam, and auxiliary classes PointLoadH, PointLoadV, DistributedLoadH, and DistributedLoadV, PointLoad and Support. # .. rubric:: Example

>>> my_beam = Beam(9)
>>> my_beam.add_supports()
>>> my_beam.add_loads([PointLoadV(-20, 3)])  # 20 kN downwards, at x=3 m
>>>

Support¶

class model.Support(coord=0, DOF=(1, 1, 1))¶

A class to represent a support.

…

_position¶

x coordinate of support on a beam

Type

(int or float)

_DOF¶

Degrees of Freedom representation

Type

(tuple of 3 bools)

_id¶

id for support on beam (assigned by beam class)

Type

int

_translation¶

represents DOF as a string translation for __str__ use

Examples

>>> Support(0, (1,1,1))  ##creates a fixed suppot at location 0
>>> Support(5, (1,1,0))  ##creatse a pinned support at location 5
>>> Support(5.54, (0,1,0))  ##creates a roller support at location 5.54

Beam¶

class model.Beam(span: float = 10, E=200000, I=60000000)¶

Represents a one-dimensional beam that can take axial and tangential loads.

Through the method add_loads, a Beam object can accept a list of:

  • PointLoad objects, and/or

  • DistributedLoad objects.

Notes

  • The default units package units for length, force and bending moment (torque) are respectively (m, kN, kN·m)

model.Beam.add_loads(self, *loads)¶

Apply an arbitrary list of (point- or distributed) loads to the beam.

Parameters

loads (iterable) – An iterable containing DistributedLoad or PointLoad objects to be applied to the Beam object. Note that the load application point (or segment) must be within the Beam span.

model.Beam.remove_loads(self, *loads)¶

Remove an arbitrary list of (point- or distributed) loads from the beam.

Parameters

loads (iterable) – An iterable containing DistributedLoad or PointLoad objects to be removed from the Beam object. If object not on beam then does nothing.

model.Beam.add_supports(self, *supports)¶

Apply an arbitrary list of supports (Support objects) to the beam.

Parameters

supports (iterable) – An iterable containing Support objects to be applied to the Beam object. Note that the load application point (or segment) must be within the Beam span.

model.Beam.remove_supports(self, *ids)¶

Remove an arbitrary list of supports (Support objects) from the beam.

Parameters

ids (iterable) – An iterable containing either Support objects or Support object ids to be removed from the Beam object. If support not on beam then does nothing.

model.Beam.get_support_details(self)¶

Print out a readable summary of all supports on the beam.

Parameters

ids (iterable) – An iterable containing either Support objects or Support object ids to be removed from the Beam object. If support not on beam then does nothing.

model.Beam.check_determinancy(self)¶

Check the determinancy of the beam.

model.Beam.analyse(self)¶

Solve the beam structure for reactoin and internal forces

Parameters

model.Beam.get_bending_moment(self, *x_coord, return_max=False, return_min=False, return_absmax=False)¶

Find the bending moment(s) on the beam object. (see get_query_value for further documentation)

model.Beam.get_shear_force(self, *x_coord, return_max=False, return_min=False, return_absmax=False)¶

Find the shear force(s) on the beam object. (see get_query_value for further documentation)

model.Beam.get_normal_force(self, *x_coord, return_max=False, return_min=False, return_absmax=False)¶

Find the normal force(s) on the beam object. (see get_query_value for further documentation)

model.Beam.get_deflection(self, *x_coord, return_max=False, return_min=False, return_absmax=False)¶

Find the deflection(s) on the beam object. (see get_query_value for further documentation)

model.Beam.add_query_points(self, *x_coords)¶

Document the forces on a beam at position x_coord when plotting.

Parameters

x_coord (list) – The x_coordinates on the beam to be queried on plot.

model.Beam.remove_query_points(self, *x_coords)¶

Remove a query point added by add_query_points function.

Parameters

x_coord (list) – The x_coordinates on the beam to be removed from query on plot.

model.Beam.plot(self, switch_axes=False, inverted=False)¶

Generates a single figure with 4 plots corresponding respectively to:

  • a schematic of the loaded beam

  • normal force diagram,

  • shear force diagram, and

  • bending moment diagram.

These plots can be generated separately with dedicated functions.

Returns

figure – Returns a handle to a figure with the 3 subplots: Beam schematic, shear force diagram, and bending moment diagram.

Return type

~matplotlib.figure.Figure

model.Beam.plot_beam_diagram(self, ax=None)¶

Returns a schematic of the beam and all the loads applied on it.

model.Beam.plot_normal_force(self, ax=None, switch_axes=False, inverted=False, maxmin_hline: bool = True, maxmin_vline: bool = False)¶

Returns a plot of the normal force as a function of the x-coordinate.

model.Beam.plot_shear_force(self, ax=None, switch_axes=False, inverted=False, maxmin_hline: bool = True, maxmin_vline: bool = False)¶

Returns a plot of the shear force as a function of the x-coordinate.

model.Beam.plot_bending_moment(self, ax=None, switch_axes=False, inverted=False, maxmin_hline: bool = True, maxmin_vline: bool = False)¶

Returns a plot of the bending moment as a function of the x-coordinate.

model.Beam.plot_deflection(self, ax=None, switch_axes=False, inverted=False, maxmin_hline: bool = True, maxmin_vline: bool = False)¶

Returns a plot of the beam deflection as a function of the x-coordinate.

PointTorque¶

class model.PointTorque(torque, coord)¶

Point clockwise torque, described by a tuple of floats: (torque, coord).

Examples

>>> motor_torque = PointTorque(30, 4)  # 30 kN·m (clockwise) torque at x=4 m

PointLoad¶

class model.PointLoad(force, coord, angle)¶

Point load described by a tuple of floats: (force, coord, angle).

Angle is in range 0 to 90 where 0 degrees is purely vertical and 90 degrees is purely horizontal

Examples

>>> external_force = PointLoadH(10, 9, 90)  # 10 kN towards the right at x=9 m
>>> external_force = PointLoadV(-30, 3, 0)  # 30 kN downwards at x=3 m
>>> external_force
PointLoadV(force=-30, coord=3, angle=0)
class model.PointLoadH(force, coord)¶

Horizontal point load described by a tuple of floats: (force, coord).

Examples

>>> external_force = PointLoadH(10, 9)  # 10 kN towards the right at x=9 m
>>> external_force
PointLoadH(force=10, coord=9)
class model.PointLoadV(force, coord)¶

Vertical point load described by a tuple of floats: (force, coord).

Examples

>>> external_force = PointLoadV(-30, 3)  # 30 kN downwards at x=3 m
>>> external_force
PointLoadV(force=-30, coord=3)

DistributedLoad¶

class model.DistributedLoadV(expr, span)¶

Distributed vertical load, described by its functional form and application interval.

Examples

>>> snow_load = DistributedLoadV("10*x+5", (0, 2))  # Linearly growing load for 0<x<2 m
>>> trapezoidal_load = DistributedLoadV("-5 + 10 * x), (1,2)) # Linearly growing load starting at 5kN/m ending at 15kn/m
>>> UDL = DistributedLoadV(10, (1,3))
